name: Individual identification number
description: PERSONID is an identification variable constructed by IPUMS using the reference ID variable (REFID) from the public use files.  The original variable identifying individuals uniquely across samples is composed of alpha-numerics, whereas PERSONID used an algorithm to create unique numeric values for each individual.  Each digit was expanded to 2 digits.  Numeric digits were given a leading zero.  For example, the digit 2 would be converted to 02.  Letters would be converted by the ordinal of the letter plus ten.  For example, A would be converted to 11, B to 12, C to 13 and so on.  It is possible to identify individuals in different survey years within the same decade.IPUMS-SESTAT has set PERSONID as a character string for statistical packages to more easily read in the values.Users should note that some respondents are interviewed over time, allowing the possibility for longitudinal data analysis.  Please see our User Note on Longitudinal Data.

name: Reference ID number (original)
description: REFID is the original individual reference number constructed by the NSF to identify respondents across surveys.  Some cohorts have alphabetic characters in addition to numeric characters, so IPUMS created an entirely numeric version called PERSONID.  Users should note that some respondents are interviewed over time, allowing the possibility for longitudinal data analysis.  Please see our User Note on Longitudinal Data.

name: Survey year
description: YEAR gives the year in which the survey was administered.

name: SESTAT weight
description: WEIGHT is a weight variable specific to SESTAT samples. The original weights for the separate, non-SESTAT surveys were adjusted to create WEIGHT, so that individuals who might have been eligible for more than one survey are not over-represented when analyzing the entire SESTAT file for a particular year.  Users should use WTSURVY for non-SESTAT survey samples.The original data includes the decimal point and 2 decimal places.

name: Sample identifier
description: SAMPLE is an IPUMS-design sample identification number to distinguish each SESTAT sample uniquely.  The sample coding convention is as follows: the left-most digit (or two digits in 4-digit codes) sequentially numbers each iteration of survey waves beginning in 1993, the second from the right digit identifies SESTAT samples with 0, and non-SESTAT (full survey) samples with 1, and the right-most digit corresponds to the survey type, for example, SDR samples have a last digit of 2.

name: Survey identifier
description: SURID identifies the survey for which the respondent was interviewed in this particular survey year.

name: Survey cohort
description: COHORT identifies to which survey cohort the respondent belongs.  For the National Survey of College Graduates (NSCG), a cohort is selected from the decennial Census or the American Community Survey sample at the beginning of each decade, and the cohort is followed over the decade.  New waves of respondents are selected by different sampling methods for the National Survey of Recent College Graduates (NSRCG) and the Survey of Doctorate Recipients (SDR) every 2 to 3 years.  The SDR respondents are not interviewed again, but the NSRCG respondents are pooled with the NSCG of that decade and interviewed until the end of the decade.  See our User Notes on Sample Design or Longitudinal Data for more details.

name: Survey mode
description: SRVMODE describes the way in which the respondent was interviewed for the survey.

name: Sequence number
description: SEQNUM is a variable constructed by IPUMS that preserves the original order of records within each sample in the public use files.  The sequence number is assigned independently for each survey component of SESTAT files.

name: Age
description: AGE is a public use version of the respondent's age at the time of the survey.  In most samples, AGE is top-coded at 75 and bottom-coded at 23, 27, or 35.For SESTAT samples in the years 1993 to 1999, AGE is a recode using the variable BIRYR, which is the respondent's birth year, given in 5-year intervals.  The result is that AGE is also given in 5-year intervals, because the recode subtracts the value in BIRYR from the survey year.

name: Birth year
description: BIRYR reports the respondent's year of birth within 5-year interval groups. For samples in years 2001 and onward, BIRYR is calculated by subtracting the respondent's age in AGE from the survey year, and recoded to match the 5-year interval scheme.

name: Gender
description: GENDER indicates whether the respondent identified as male or female.

name: Minority indicator
description: MINRTY is an indicator variable identifying respondents who self-reported being an ethnic or racial minority.

name: Race/ethnicity
description: RACETH is a recode of the respondent's reported race into public use categories.  The specific categories Asian and White are kept, and other race categories that have fewer cases are grouped into Under-represented minorities or Other.

name: Place of birth
description: BTHUS reports whether or not the respondent was born in the United States.

name: U.S. citizenship status, binary
description: CTZUSIN is a binary variable that indicates whether or not the respondent is a US citizen or not.  The variable CTZUS gives more detail about whether the respondent is a citizen by birth or by naturalization.

name: Type of US citizen
description: CTZUS reports whether the respondent is a citizen by birth or by naturalization.  A similar variable CTZUSIN is a binary variable that indicates whether or not the respondent is a US citizen or not.

name: Type of visa held when first came to US
description: FNVS describes the respondent's visa category when he/she first came to the US.

name: Total number of children
description: CHTOT is an NSF recode variable describing how many children the respondent lived with as part of his/her family.

name: Number of children: under age 2
description: CHU2 gives the number of children under the age of 2 who live with the respondent as of the reference date.

name: Children indicator: under age 2
description: CHU2IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children under the age of two, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Number of children: under age 6
description: CH6 gives the number of children under the age of 6 who lived with the respondent, if the respondent reported living with children.

name: Children indicator: under age 6
description: CH6IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children under the age of 6, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Number of children: aged 2-5
description: CH25 gives the number of children between the ages of 2 and 5 who live with the respondent as of the reference date.

name: Children indicator: ages 2-5
description: CH25IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children who were between the ages 2 and 5, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Number of children: aged 6-11
description: CH611 gives the number of children ages 6 to 11 who lived with the respondent, if the respondent reported living with children.

name: Children indicator: ages 6-11
description: CH611IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children who were between the ages 6 and 11, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Children indicator: under 12
description: CHUN12 indicates whether the respondent lived with a child under age 12.

name: Number of children: aged 12-17
description: CH1217 gives the number of children ages 12 to 17 who lived with the respondent, if the respondent reported living with children.

name: Children indicator: aged 12-17
description: CH1217IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children who were between the ages 12 and 17, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Children indicator: aged 12-18
description: CH1218IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children who were between the ages 12 and 18, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Number of children: aged 18 or older
description: CH18 gives the number of children ages 18 or older who lived with the respondent, if the respondent reported living with children.

name: Children indicator: aged 18 or older
description: CH18IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children ages 18 or older, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Children indicator: age 19 or older
description: CH19IN is a binary variable that indicates whether the respondent lived with children ages 19 or older, if the respondent lived with children.

name: Respondent location
description: RESPLCUS indicates whether or not the respondent was located in the US or not, using information from other responses, such as respondent's residence or employer's location.

name: Reasons for coming to U.S.: most important reason
description: CMPRI reports the factor the respondent considered most important when deciding to come to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US.  Related variables include CMEDU, CMFAM, CMFLD, CMOPP, CMOT, and CMSEC.

name: Reasons for coming to U.S.: second most important reason
description: CMSEC reports the factor the respondent considered second most important when deciding to come to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US.  Related variables include CMEDU, CMFAM, CMFLD, CMOPP, CMOT, and CMPRI.

name: Factors important to come to U.S.: educational opportunities
description: CMEDU reports whether or not opportunities for education was a factor in the respondent's decision for coming to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US.  Related variables include CMFAM, CMFLD, CMOPP, CMOT, CMPRI, and CMSEC.

name: Factors important to come to U.S.: family-related reasons
description: CMFAM reports whether or not family-related reasons were a factor in the respondent's decision for coming to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US. Related variables include CMEDU, CMFLD, CMOPP, CMOT, CMPRI, and CMSEC.

name: Factors important to come to U.S.: scientific/professional infrastructure
description: CMFLD reports whether or not scientific or professional infrastructure in the respondent's field were a factor in the respondent's decision for coming to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US. Related variables include CMEDU, CMFAM, CMOPP, CMOT, CMPRI, and CMSEC.

name: Factors important to come to U.S.: job/economic opportunities
description: CMOPP reports whether or not job or economic opportunities were a factor in the respondent's decision for coming to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US. Related variables include CMEDU, CMFAM, CMFLD, CMOT, CMPRI, and CMSEC.

name: Factors important to come to U.S.: other
description: CMOT reports whether a factor other than the ones listed on the questionnaire affected the respondent's decision for coming to the United States, if the respondent was a US citizen but not born in the US. Related variables include CMEDU, CMFAM, CMFLD, CMOPP, CMPRI, and CMSEC.

name: Year of first bachelor's degree pre-2003 (5-year intervals)
description: BAAYR5 is the year the respondent was awarded his/her first bachelor's degree, grouped into 5-year intervals.  In some samples, the month of the receipt of the first bachelor's degree is available in BAMN.  The year of achieving a bachelor's degree without intervals is available in some samples in the variable BAACYR.

name: Year of first bachelor degree 2003-onward (5-year intervals)
description: BA03Y5 is the year the respondent was awarded his/her first bachelor's degree, grouped into 5-year intervals, for samples 2003 and after. For comparable data pre-2003, see BAAYR5.  In some samples, the month of the receipt of the first bachelor's degree is available in BAMN.  The year of achieving a bachelor's degree without intervals is available in some samples in the variable BAACYR.

name: Field of major for first bachelor degree code
description: NBAMED provides a public-use version of respondent's field of major for his/her first bachelor's degree. Related variables include NBAMEDD and NBAMEMG.

name: Field of major for first bachelor degree (major group)
description: NBAMEMG categorizes the respondent's field of major for his/her first bachelor's degree into eight broad fields. The variable NBAMED provides this information with a finer level of detail.

name: Location of school awarding first bachelor's degree (region)
description: BARGN reports the location of the school from which the respondent received his or her first bachelor's degree.

name: Location of school awarding first bachelor degree (US/non-US)
description: BADGRUS reports whether or not the academic institution where the respondent achieved his/her first bachelor's degree is located in the US.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Assistantship/work study
description: BAFAST indicates whether or not the respondent depended on financial support from an assistantship or work study during his/her first bachelor's degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFEM, BAFERN, BAFGFT, BAFGRN, BAFLN, BAFOT, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Employer
description: BAFEM indicates whether or not the respondent depended on financial support from his/her employer during his/her first bachelor's degree. The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied. Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFERN, BAFGFT, BAFGRN, BAFLN, BAFOT, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Earnings from employment
description: BAFERN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on earnings from employment as financial support during his/her first bachelor's degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFEM, BAFGFT, BAFGRN, BAFLN, BAFOT, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Gifts
description: BAFGFT indicates whether or not the respondent depended on gifts from parents or other relatives as financial support during his/her first bachelor's degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFEM, BAFERN, BAFGRN, BAFLN, BAFOT, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Grants
description: BAFGRN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on tuition waivers, fellowships, grants, or scholarships as financial support during his/her first bachelor's degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFEM, BAFERN, BAFGFT, BAFLN, BAFOT, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Loans
description: BAFLN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on loans from the academic institution, banks, or government as financial support during his/her first bachelor's degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFEM, BAFERN, BAFGFT, BAFGRN, BAFOT, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Other
description: BAFOT indicates whether or not the respondent depended on a source of financial support during his/her first bachelor's degree other than the potential sources listed on the questionnaire.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFEM, BAFERN, BAFGFT, BAFGRN, BAFLN, and BAFPLN.

name: Financial support for first bachelor degree: Loans from relatives
description: BAFPLN indicates whether or not the respondent depended loans from parents or relatives as financial support during his/her first bachelor's degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include BAFAST, BAFEM, BAFERN, BAFGFT, BAFGRN, BAFLN, and BAFOT.

name: Type of highest certificate or degree
description: DGRDG reports the type of the respondent's highest postsecondary degree or certificate.

name: Year of highest degree pre-2003 (5 year intervals)
description: HDAY5 reports the year, recoded to intervals, in which the respondent received his/her highest degree.  The variable HD03Y5 provides similar information for different samples.

name: Year of highest degree 2003-onward (5 year intervals)
description: HD03Y5 reports the year, in 5-year intervals, in which the respondent received his/her highest degree (for all samples 2003 and after). For the comparable variable pre-2003, see HDAY5.

name: Field of major for highest degree
description: NDGMED provides the respondent's field of major for his/her highest degree. The variable NDGMEMG provides this information with a broader level of detail.

name: Field of major for highest degree (major group)
description: NDGMEMG categorizes the field of major for the respondent's highest degree into seven broad fields. The variable NDGMED provides this information with a finer level of detail.

name: Location of school awarding highest degree
description: HDRGN reports the location of the school from which the respondent received his or her highest degree.

name: School awarding highest degree located in the US
description: HDDGRUS identifies whether or not the academic institution where the respondent received his/her highest degree was located in the United States or not.  Due to the sample design of the SDR survey, SDR respondents have all received their doctorate (which is their highest degree) from an institution in the US.  See our Survey Designs User Note for more information.

name: Financial support for highest degree: assistantship/work study
description: HDFAST indicates whether or not the respondent depended on financial support from an assistantship or work study during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFEM, HDFERN, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFLN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: financial assistance from employer
description: HDFEM indicates whether or not the respondent depended on financial support from his/her employer during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFERN, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFLN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: earnings from employment
description: HDFERN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on earnings from employment as financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFLN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: gifts
description: HDFGFT indicates whether or not the respondent depended on gifts from parents or other relatives as financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFERN, HDFGRN, HDFLN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: grants
description: HDFGRN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on tuition waivers, fellowships, grants, or scholarships as financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFERN, HDFGFT, HDFLN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: loans
description: HDFLN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on loans from the academic institution, banks, or government as financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFERN, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: other
description: HDFOT indicates whether or not the respondent depended on a source of financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree other than the potential sources listed on the questionnaire.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFERN, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFLN, and HDFPLN.

name: Financial support for highest degree: loans from parents, other relatives
description: HDFPLN indicates whether or not the respondent depended loans from parents or relatives as financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFERN, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFLN, and HDFOT.

name: Likelihood of choosing same field of study for highest degree
description: SAMEFLD describes how likely the respondent would be to choose the same field of degree for their highest degree if they had the chance to choose again.

name: Type of degree, most recent degree
description: MRDG indicates the type of degree the respondent received most recently.

name: Year of most recent degree (5-year intervals, 2003+)
description: MR03Y5 reports the year, in 5-year intervals, in which the respondent received his/her most recent degree, post 2003. MR5YR reports similar information, but prior to 2003.

name: Year of most recent degree (5-year intervals, pre-2003)
description: MR5YR reports the year, recoded to intervals, in which the respondent received his/her most recent degree.  MR5YR is only available for samples prior to 2003, but the variable MR03Y5 also provides similar information for 2003-onward.

name: Field of major for most recent degree
description: NMRMEDR provides a public-use version of respondent's field of study of major for most recent degree. The related variable NMRMEMG provides a more general categorization of the information found in NMRMEDR.

name: Field of study of major for most recent degree (major group)
description: NMRMEMG categorizes the field of study of major for the respondent's most recent degree into eight broad fields. The variable NMRMEDR provides this information with a finer level of detail.

name: Location of school awarding most recent degree
description: MRRGN reports the location of the academic institution from which the respondent received his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The geographic level is at the US region level, with a category to identify institutions outside of the US.

name: School awarding most recent degree located in the US
description: MRDGRUS reports whether or not the academic institution from which the respondent received his/her most recent post-secondary degree was located in the United States.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: assistantship/work study
description: MRFAST indicates whether or not the respondent depended on financial support from an assistantship or work study during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFEM, MRFERN, MRFGFT, MRFGRN, MRFLN, MRFOT, and MRFPLN.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: financial assistance from employer
description: MRFEM indicates whether or not the respondent depended on financial support from his/her employer during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFERN, MRFGFT, MRFGRN, MRFLN, MRFOT, and MRFPLN.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: earnings from employment
description: MRFERN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on earnings from employment as financial support during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFEM, MRFGFT, MRFGRN, MRFLN, MRFOT, and MRFPLN.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: gifts
description: MRFGFT indicates whether or not the respondent depended on gifts from parents or other relatives as financial support during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFEM, MRFERN, MRFGRN, MRFLN, MRFOT, and MRFPLN.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: grants
description: MRFGRN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on tuition waivers, fellowships, grants, or scholarships as financial support during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFEM, MRFERN, MRFGFT, MRFLN, MRFOT, and MRFPLN.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: loans
description: MRFLN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on loans from the academic institution, banks, or government as financial support during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFEM, MRFERN, MRFGFT, MRFGRN, MRFOT, and MRFPLN.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: loans from parents, other relatives
description: MRFPLN indicates whether or not the respondent depended loans from parents or relatives as financial support during his/her most recent post-secondary degree.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFEM, MRFERN, MRFGFT, MRFGRN, MRFLN, and MRFOT.

name: Financial support, most recent degree: other
description: MRFOT indicates whether or not the respondent depended on a source of financial support during his/her most recent post-secondary degree other than the potential sources listed on the questionnaire.  The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied.  Other variables from this survey question include MRFAST, MRFEM, MRFERN, MRFGFT, MRFGRN, MRFLN, and MRFPLN.

name: Two-year associates degree
description: ASDGRI indicates whether or not the respondent holds a 2-year associates degree as of the reference week.

name: Attended community college
description: COMCOLI indicates whether or not the respondent ever enrolled in courses at a community college.

name: Reasons attend community college: complete associates degree
description: CCASDG indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes as part of an advanced placement program in high school.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT,  CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: complete credit towards bachelors degree
description: CCBSDG indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes in order to complete credits towards a bachelor's degree.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCCHGFL, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT,  CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: change academic/occupational field
description: CCCHGFL indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes in order to change his/her academic or occupational field.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT,  CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: prepare for college
description: CCCOLPR indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes in order to prepare for college.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT,  CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: financial reasons
description: CCFIN indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes for financial reasons.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT,  CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: leisure
description: CCINT indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes simply for leisure or personal interest.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCOT,  CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: other
description: CCOT indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes for a reason other the ones listed on the questionnaire.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCPRAD, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: increase opportunities for promotion
description: CCPRAD indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes in order to increase opportunities for promotion or advancement.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT, and CCSKL.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Reasons attend community college: acquire further skills in field
description: CCSKL indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes in order to acquire further skills in his/her academic or occupational field.  Other reasons respondents could have given for taking community college classes can be found in the variables CCADVPL, CCASDG, CCBSDG, CCCHGFL, CCCOLPR, CCFIN, CCGED, CCINT, CCOT, and CCPRAD.  The variable CCAFDG indicates whether the respondent was in the universe for this question.

name: Full-time/part-time student status
description: ACFPT reports whether the respondent was taking courses full-time, part-time, or not enrolled in a degree program even though they were taking classes.

name: Taking courses during reference week
description: ACSIN indicates whether the respondent was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program during the reference week.

name: Type of degree working on during reference week
description: ACDRG gives the type of degree the respondent was working towards during the reference week.

name: Took college courses after completing most recent degree
description: CCAFDG indicates whether or not the respondent chose to enroll in community college classes after completing his/her most recent degree.

name: Type of degree working on since after college
description: If the respondent had taken a course after completing his/her college degree, TCDG indicates the type of degree for which the respondent took courses.

name: Completed a degree since the last survey
description: TCDGCM reports whether or not the respondent completed a post-secondary degree between the reference month of the survey and the last iteration of that survey, which is typically a period of 2 to 3 years.  TCDG indicates the type of degree the respondent was working on since the completed degree the respondent was sampled for.

name: Field of major for field of study after most recent degree
description: For respondents who took college courses after completing the sample degree, TCED describes the field of degree of the courses.

name: Field of study after earning degree
description: If a respondent had taken college-level courses after earning his/her most recent degree, PFMAEDGR indicates the general field of degree to which the courses belonged.

name: Field of major for current degree (major code)
description: NACEDMG categorizes the respondent's field of study during the reference week into seven broad fields.

name: No primary field of study in courses after college
description: TCEDNO indicates that a respondent who took college courses after his/her most recent degree did not have a primary field of study in those courses.

name: Reasons for taking courses: increase advancement opportunities
description: ACADV indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was to increase opportunities for promotion, career advancement, or a higher salary.  The survey question from which ACADV was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACCAR, ACCHG,  ACEM, ACGRD, ACINT, ACLIC, ACOT, ACOTP, and ACSKL.

name: Reasons for taking courses: further education before career
description: ACCAR indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was to gain further education before beginning a career.  The survey question from which ACCAR was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACADV, ACCHG,  ACEM, ACGRD, ACINT, ACLIC, ACOT, ACOTP, and ACSKL.

name: Reasons for taking courses: facilitate academic/occupational field change
description: ACCHG indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was to change his/her academic or occupational field.  The survey question from which ACCHG was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACADV, ACCAR,  ACEM, ACGRD, ACINT, ACLIC, ACOT, ACOTP, and ACSKL.

name: Reason for taking courses during reference week: leisure/personal interest
description: ACINT indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was for leisure or personal interest.  The survey question from which ACINT was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACADV, ACCAR, ACCHG, ACEM, ACGRD, ACLIC, ACOT, ACOTP, and ACSKL.

name: Reason for taking courses during reference week: licensure/certification
description: ACLIC indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was to attain licensure or a certification.  The survey question from which ACLIC was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACADV, ACCAR, ACCHG, ACEM, ACGRD, ACINT, ACOT, ACOTP, and ACSKL.

name: Reason for taking courses during reference week: grad school, required by employer, other
description: ACOTP indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was that his/her employer required it, to prepare for graduate school, or for another reason that was not listed in the questionnaire.  The survey question from which ACOTP was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACADV, ACCAR, ACCHG, ACEM, ACGRD, ACINT, ACLIC, ACOT, and ACSKL.Users should note that another variable, ACOT, also indicates a reason not listed for the respondent enrolling in classes during the reference week.  The difference between the two variables is that in the SESTAT NSCG 2013, the reason required or expected by employer was separated into its own category, whereas in ACOTP would include this reason in samples prior to 2013.

name: Reason for taking courses during reference week: gain further skills in field
description: ACSKL indicates whether the reason that the respondent was enrolled in classes in the reference week was to gain further skills in his/her field.  The survey question from which ACSKL was derived asks the respondent to mark all reasons why he/she was taking courses or enrolled in a degree program.  Related variables include ACADV, ACCAR, ACCHG, ACEM, ACGRD, ACINT, ACLIC, ACOT, and ACOTP.

name: Reasons for taking courses: expected/required by employer
description: TCEM indicates whether or not the respondent took college courses after his/her most recent degree because his/her employer expected or required them.

name: Reasons for taking courses: prepare for graduate school
description: TCGRD indicates whether or not the respondent took college courses after his/her most recent degree in order to prepare for graduate school.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: needed break
description: NCBRK indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because he/she needed a break. Other variables from this survey question include NCCHG, NCFAM, NCFIN, NCGOAL, NCJOB, NCMOVE, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: no longer certain of field
description: NCCHG indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because he/she was no longer certain of the field of study he/she wanted to pursue. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCFAM, NCFIN, NCGOAL, NCJOB, NCMOVE, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: family
description: NCFAM indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because of family reasons. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFIN, NCGOAL, NCJOB, NCMOVE, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: financial reasons
description: NCFIN indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because of financial reasons. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFAM, NCGOAL, NCJOB, NCMOVE, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: achieved educational goals
description: NCGOAL indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because he/she had achieved his/her education goals. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFAM, NCFIN, NCJOB, NCMOVE, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: job
description: NCJOB indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because he/she had a job and/or needed to work. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFAM, NCGOAL, NCFIN, NCMOVE, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: moved
description: NCMOVE indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because he/she moved and was then unable to continue taking courses at the academic institution he/she had been attending. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFAM, NCGOAL, NCFIN, NCJOB, NCTERM, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: waiting for next school term
description: NCTERM indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses because he/she was waiting for next school term to begin. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFAM, NCGOAL, NCFIN, NCJOB, NCMOVE, and NCOT.

name: Reasons for not taking courses: other
description: NCOT indicates whether or not the respondent was not taking courses for a reason other than the reasons listed in the questionnaire. Other variables from this survey question include NCBRK, NCCHG, NCFAM, NCGOAL, NCFIN, NCJOB, NCMOVE, NCTERM.

name: School-related costs paid by employer
description: ACCCEP indicates that any of the respondent's school-related costs were covered by his/her employer.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: assistantships/work study
description: FAAST indicates whether or not the respondent relied on assistantship or work study as financial support for taking courses after receiving his/her most recent degree.  Related variables describing sources of financial support include FAEM, FAERN, FAGFT, FAGRN, FALN, FAOT, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: employer
description: FAEM reports whether or not the respondent relied on financial support from his/her employer in order to take courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAERN, FAGFT, FAGRN, FALN, FAOT, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: earnings from employment
description: FAERN reports whether or not the respondent relied earnings from employment as a way to finance enrollment in courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAEM, FAGFT, FAGRN, FALN, FAOT, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: gifts parents/relatives
description: FAGFT reports whether or not the respondent relied on financial support from his/her parents (without the expectation of repayment) in order to take courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAEM, FAERN, FAGRN, FALN, FAOT, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: grants/scholarships/etc.
description: FAGRN reports whether or not the respondent relied on financial support from grants, scholarships, fellowships, or tuition waivers in order to take courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAEM, FAERN, FAGFT, FALN, FAOT, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: loans from institution
description: FALN reports whether or not the respondent relied on financial support in the form of loans from a bank, government, or the academic institution in order to take courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAEM, FAERN, FAGFT, FAGRN, FAOT, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: other
description: FAOT reports whether or not the respondent relied on a source of financial support other than the options listed on the questionnaire in order to take courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAEM, FAERN, FAGFT, FAGRN, FALN, and FAPLN.

name: Sources of financial support for courses since college: loans from parents/relatives
description: FAPLN reports whether or not the respondent relied on loans from parents as financial support in order to take courses since completing a college degree.  Related variables about financial support while taking courses after college include FAAST, FAEM, FAERN, FAGFT, FAGRN, FALN, and FAOT.

name: Year received high school diploma (group)
description: HSYRGR reports the year the respondent received his/her high school diploma, in 5-year intervals.

name: Place attended high school (recode)
description: HSUS is a recode indicating whether or not the respondent's high school was located within the United States.

name: No high school diploma (did not finish high school)
description: HSNOI is an indicator variable that reports whether or not the respondent has a high school diploma.  The response categories are somewhat counter-intuitive.  The No category means that the respondent did finish high school, and a Yes response means that the respondent did not finish high school, and therefore has no high school diploma.

name: Labor force status
description: LFSTAT is the respondent's labor force status.

name: Working for pay during reference week
description: WRKG indicates whether or not the respondent was working for pay during the survey reference week.

name: Full-time/part-time status
description: FPTIND  indicates whether or not a respondent was working full time or part-time, if he/she was working during the reference week.

name: Working both current and previous reference weeks
description: WRKGP indicates that the respondent was working for pay both during the current survey's reference period, and during the reference period of the previous survey, typically 2 or 3 years earlier.

name: Employment status, current and previous reference weeks
description: If the respondent worked during both the reference week and during the same week two years prior, he/she was asked if he/she worked for the same employer and in the same job. EMSMI describes all combinations of the respondent working for the same or a different employer, or the same or a different job.

name: Full-time, years of professional work experience
description: EXPFT gives the respondent's years of full-time, professional work experience.

name: Part-time, years of professional work experience
description: EXPPT gives the respondent's years of part-time, professional work experience.

name: Principal job hours worked
description: HRSWK reports the number of hours a week that the respondent worked at his/her principal job.  HRSWKGR is a similar variable that is gives hours per week worked in hour groups.

name: Principal job: hours per week typically worked (group)
description: HRSWKGR reports the typical hours per week that the respondent works at his/her principal job categorized into four groups.  The variable HRSWK also provides this information for SESTAT samples prior to 2000, however, HRSWK is not intervalled.

name: Principal job weeks salary based on year (group)
description: WKSWKGR reports the interval number of weeks the basic annual salary of the respondent's principal job was based on during a 52-week year, including sick leave and paid vacation.

name: Available benefits: health insurance
description: JOBINS indicates whether or not the respondent's job provides health insurance. Related variables include JOBPENS, JOBPROFT, and JOBVAC.

name: Available benefits: pension/retirement plan
description: JOBPENS indicates whether or not the respondent's job provides a pension or retirement plan. Related variables include JOBINS, JOBPROFT, and JOBVAC.

name: Available benefits: profit-sharing plan
description: JOBPROFT indicates whether or not the respondent's job had a profit-sharing plan. Related variables include JOBPENS, JOBINS,  JOBVAC.

name: Available benefits: paid vacation/sick/personal days
description: JOBVAC indicates whether or not the respondent's provides paid vacation, sick, and/or personal days.  Related variables include JOBPENS, JOBINS, and JOBPROFT.

name: Not working, looking for work
description: If the respondent was not working during the reference week, LOOKWK indicates whether or not he/she was looking for work in the four weeks preceding the reference week.

name: Have not found new job
description: FINDNO indicates whether or not the respondent, who was actively searching for a job, had not found another job at the time of the survey after losing or leaving a job.

name: Months to find new job
description: FINDTIME reports the number of months of active searching passed before the respondent found another job after losing or leaving a job.

name: Preferred type of working arrangement
description: WORKWANT describes the type of work arrangement the respondent preferred, regardless of the type of work arrangement he/she had at the time of the survey.

name: Concerned about losing job
description: LOSEJOB indicates whether or not the respondent was concerned about losing his/her job in the next 12 months.

name: Year, left/lost job
description: LOSEYR reports the year the respondent lost or left his/her job (referring to the most recent job lost or left since his/her first bachelor's degree) in 5-year intervals.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: company closed down
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSECLOS reports whether or not the respondent's company, facility, or agency closed down and caused the loss of the job.  LOSECLOS is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSEMOVE, LOSEOTHR, LOSEREOR, LOSEREV, LOSESELF, and LOSETAKE.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: company moved
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSEMOVE reports whether or not the respondent's company, facility, or agency moved and caused the loss of the job.  LOSEMOVE is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSECLOS, LOSEOTHR, LOSEREOR, LOSEREV, LOSESELF, and LOSETAKE.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: other
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSEOTHR reports whether or not a reason other than those listed on the questionnaire caused the respondent to lose his/her job.  LOSEOTHR is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSECLOS, LOSEMOVE, LOSEREOR, LOSEREV, LOSESELF, and LOSETAKE.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: work reorganized/restructured
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSEREOR reports whether or not his/her company's reorganization or restructure caused the loss of the job.  LOSEREOR is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSECLOS, LOSEMOVE, LOSEOTHR, LOSEREV, LOSESELF, and LOSETAKE.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: company had insufficient revenue
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSEREV reports whether or not his/her company's insufficient revenue caused the loss of the job.  LOSEREV is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSECLOS, LOSEMOVE, LOSEOTHR, LOSEREOR, LOSESELF, and LOSETAKE.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: self-operated business ended
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSESELF reports whether or not his/her self-owned business end caused the loss of the job.  LOSESELF is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSECLOS, LOSEMOVE, LOSEOTHR, LOSEREOR, LOSEREV, and LOSETAKE.

name: Reasons for losing/leaving job: company taken over
description: If a respondent lost or left a job (as indicated by DOWNSIZE) since his/her first bachelor's degree, LOSETAKE reports whether or not the takeover of his/her company caused the loss of the job.  LOSETAKE is among a series of variables regarding the reason for the respondent losing his/her job, which also includes LOSECLOS, LOSEMOVE, LOSEOTHR, LOSEREOR, LOSEREV, and LOSESELF.

name: Lost or left job due to employer closing or downsizing
description: DOWNSIZE indicates whether the respondent lost or left his/her last job due to an employer closing or downsizing.

name: Previously retired
description: FTPRET indicates whether or not a respondent, who was working during the reference week, had been retired previously.

name: Reasons for working part-time: retired
description: PTRET indicates whether or not the respondent was working part time because he/she was retired.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTOTP, and PTSTU.

name: Working part-time but wanted to work full-time
description: PTWTFT indicated whether or not respondents who worked part time actually wanted to be working full time.

name: Reasons for working part-time: family
description: PTFAM indicates that the respondent worked part-time during the reference week because of family reasons.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTOTP, PTRET, and PTSTU.

name: Reasons for working part-time: illness/disability
description: PTILL indicates whether the respondent was working part time during the reference week because of illness or disability.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTOTP, PTRET, and PTSTU.

name: Reasons for working part-time: not need/want work
description: PTNOND indicates that the respondent worked part time in the reference week because the respondent did not need to or want to work full time.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM,  PTILL, PTOCNA, PTOTP, PTRET, and PTSTU.

name: Reasons for working part-time: suitable full-time job not available
description: PTOCNA indicates that the respondent worked part time during the reference week because a suitable full-time job was not available at the time.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTNOND, PTOTP, PTRET, and PTSTU.

name: Reasons for working part-time: other
description: PTOTP indicates whether there was a reason other than the reasons listed in the questionnaire to explain why the respondent was working part time during the reference week.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTRET, and PTSTU.

name: Reasons for working part-time: student
description: PTSTU indicates whether or not the respondent was working part time because he/she was a student during the reference period.  The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTOTP, and PTRET.

name: Principal job related to highest degree
description: OCEDRLP describes whether or not the respondent's principal job was related to his/her highest post-secondary degree.

name: Job code for principal job
description: NOCPR provides the occupation code of the respondent's principal job. The variable NOCPRMG provides the same information at a more aggregated level.

name: Job code for principal job (major group)
description: NOCPRMG categorizes the occupation code of the respondent's principal job into seven broad fields. The variable NOCPR provides this information with a finer level of detail.

name: Relationship of second job to highest degree
description: OCSEDRL describes whether or not the respondent's second job was related to his/her highest post-secondary degree.

name: Second job during reference week
description: OCSI indicates whether or not the respondent worked a second job in addition to a principal job during the reference week.  The occupation code for this job can be found in the variable OCS.

name: Job code for second job
description: OCS reports the respondent's occupation for his/her second job, if he/she held a second job during the reference week.

name: Job code for second job (major group)
description: OCSMG reports the respondent's occupation for his/her second job, if he/she held a second job during the reference week.  OCS is a similar variable that is available for a greater number of samples.

name: Employer sector
description: EMSEC gives the summary level or general version of the sector of the respondent's main employer.

name: Size of employer
description: EMSIZE describes the size of the respondent's main employer by the number of employees.

name: Employer: main business
description: EMBUS provides the broad business category to which the respondent's main employer belongs.  There are 13 business categories which include agriculture, manufacturing, and health services.

name: Principal employer came into being as a new business within last 5 years
description: NEWBUS reports whether or not the respondent's principal employer came into being as a new business within the past 5 years.

name: Employer located in the US
description: EMUS is a binary variable indicating whether the respondent's employer location being in the US or not.  A more detailed variable providing similar geographic employer region information is EMRG.

name: US region code for employer
description: EMRG gives the location of the respondent at the geographic level of US region, and identifies non-US employers.  The regions correspond to US Census region divisions.

name: Federal government support indicator
description: GOVSUP indicates whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the federal government.  If yes, the respondent was also asked which department or agency supplied the funding.  These answers can be found in a series of variables beginning with FS in the Employment - Other variable category.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Agriculture
description: FSAGR reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Agriculture.  FSAGR is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: AID
description: FSAID reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Agency for International Development.  FSAID is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Commerce
description: FSCOM reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Commerce.  FSCOM is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Education
description: FSDED reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Education.  FSDED is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Agency unknown
description: FSDK reports whether or not the respondent knew his/her work was supported by a federal department or agency, but did not know which department or agency.  FSDK is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Defense
description: FSDOD reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Defense.  FSDOD is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Energy
description: FSDOE reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Energy.  FSDOE is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Transportation
description: FSDOT reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Transportation.  FSDOT is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: EPA
description: FSEPA reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Environmental Protection Agency.  FSEPA is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: HHS
description: FSHHS reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Health and Human Services.  FSHHS is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: HUD
description: FSHUD reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Housing and Urban Development.  FSHUD is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Interior
description: FSINT reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of the Interior.  FSINT is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Justice
description: FSJUS reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Justice.  FSJUS is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Labor
description: FSLAB reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Labor.  FSLAB is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: NASA
description: FSNASA reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).  FSNASA is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: NIH
description: FSNIH reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US National Institutes of Health.  FSNIH is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: NRC
description: FSNRC reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US National Regulatory Commission.  FSNRC is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: NSF
description: FSNSF reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US National Science Foundation.  FSNSF is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: Other
description: FSOT reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by a federal agency or department other than the ones listed on the questionnaire.  FSOT is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: State
description: FSST reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US State Department.  FSST is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Federal agency supporting work: VA
description: FSVA reports whether or not the respondent's work was supported by the US Department of Veteran Affairs.  FSVA is part of a series of variables that indicate all federal departments and agencies that might have supported the respondent's work.

name: Most hours, work activity
description: WAPRI categorizes the primary work activity the respondent performs during a typical work week in his/her principal job.  Related variables regarding work activities include WAPRSM, WASEC, and WASCSM.

name: Summarized primary work activity
description: WAPRSM identifies a summary-level version of the respondent's primary work activity during a typical work week in his/her principal job.  Related variables regarding work activities include WAPRI,  WASEC, and WASCSM.

name: Second most hours, work activity
description: WASEC categorizes the secondary work activity the respondent performs during a typical work week in his/her principal job.  Related variables regarding work activities include WAPRI, WAPRSM, and WASCSM.

name: Summarized secondary work activity
description: WASCSM identifies a summary-level version of the respondent's secondary work activity during a typical work week in his/her principal job.  Related variables regarding work activities include WAPRI, WASEC, and WAPRSM.

name: Area devoted most hours
description: PRIAREA describes the topic area where the respondent devoted most of his/her work hours.

name: Activity, computer applications
description: ACTCAP indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves computer applications.  ACTCAP is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTDED, ACTMGT, ACTRD, ACTRDT, ACTRES, and ACTTCH.ACTCAP is an NSF recode using information from variables including WACOM.

name: Activity, development and design
description: ACTDED indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves development and design.  ACTDED is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTCAP, ACTMGT, ACTRD, ACTRDT, ACTRES, and ACTTCH.ACTDED is an NSF recode using information from variables including WADEV and WADSN.

name: Activity, management/sales
description: ACTMGT indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves management and/or sales.  ACTMGT is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTCAP, ACTDED, ACTRD, ACTRDT, ACTRES, and ACTTCH.ACTMGT is an NSF recode using information from variables including WAMGMT and WASALE.

name: Activity, research and development
description: ACTRD indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves research and development.  ACTRD is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTCAP, ACTDED, ACTMGT, ACTRDT, ACTRES, and ACTTCH.ACTRD is an NSF recode using information from variables including WAAPRSH, WABRSH and WADEV.

name: Activity, research, development, and teaching
description: ACTRDT indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves research, development, and teaching.  ACTRDT is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTCAP, ACTDED, ACTMGT, ACTRD, ACTRES, and ACTTCH.ACTRDT is an NSF recode using information from variables including WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WADEV and WATEA.

name: Activity, research (basic and/or applied)
description: ACTRES indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves basic and/or applied research.  ACTRES is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTCAP, ACTDED, ACTMGT, ACTRD, ACTRDT, and ACTTCH.ACTRES is an NSF recode using information from variables including WAAPRSH and WABRSH,.

name: Activity, teaching
description: ACTTCH indicates whether the work activities in the respondent's primary job involves teaching.  ACTTCH is derived from a question that lists a number of work activities, and the respondent is asked to check a box next to the work activity that occupied at least 10 percent of the respondent's time in a typical work week.  Related variables include ACTCAP, ACTDED, ACTMGT, ACTRD, ACTRDT, and ACTRES.ACTTCH differs from a similar variable WATEA in that ACTTCH is an NSF recode using the same question as WATEA, whereas WATEA is the original response.

name: Work activities on principal job: development
description: WADEV indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in development during a typical work week.  In the survey, development is defined as using knowledge gained from research for the production of materials or devices.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: design
description: WADSN indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in designing equipment, processes, structures, and/or models during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: employee relations
description: WAEMRL indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in employee relations, including recruiting, personnel development, and training, during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: management and administration
description: WAMGMT indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in managing and supervising during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: other
description: WAOT indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in an activity other than the activities listed in the questionnaire during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: production, operations, maintenance
description: WAPROD indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in production, operations, and maintenance during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: quality or productivity management
description: WAQM indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in quality or productivity management during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: sales, purchasing, marketing
description: WASALE indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job doing sales, purchasing, marketing, customer service, or public relations during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: professional services
description: WASVC indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in professional services, including health care, counseling, legal services, etc, during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: teaching
description: WATEA indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job teaching during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, and WASVC.WATEA differs from a similar variable ACTTCH in that WATEA is the original response, whereas ACTTCH is an NSF recode using the same question as WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: accounting, finance, contracts
description: WAACC indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in accounting, finance, or contracts during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job : applied research
description: WAAPRSH indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in applied research during a typical work week.  In the survey, applied research is defined as study directed toward gaining scientific knowledge to meet a recognized need.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WABRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: basic research
description: WABRSH indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in basic research during a typical work week.  In the survey, basic research is defined as study directed toward gaining scientific knowledge for its own sake.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WACOM, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work activities on principal job: computer applications
description: WACOM indicates whether or not the respondent spent at least ten percent of time in his/her principal job in computer applications, programming, or systems development during a typical work week.  Other variables regarding work activities include WAACC, WAAPRSH, WABRSH, WADEV, WADSN, WAEMRL, WAMGMT, WAOT, WAPROD, WAQM, WASALE, WASVC, and WATEA.

name: Work on principal job: work with others in same organization
description: WKSORG indicates whether or not the respondent worked with other individuals within the same organization while performing his/her principal job.

name: Work on principal job: work with immediate group or team
description: WKTEAM indicates whether or not the respondent worked with an immediate group or team in his/her principal job.

name: Work on principal job: work with others in other US organization
description: WKUSORG indicates whether or not the respondent worked with individuals from other organizations in the US in performing his/her principal job during the week of April 1st, 2006.

name: Supervisory work
description: SUPWK indicates whether or not the respondent supervised other employees as a part of his/her principal job.

name: Number of papers (co)authored presented
description: PAPERS reports the number of papers the respondent had authored or co-authored that had been presented at conferences since October 1998.

name: Number of papers presented (intervaled)
description: PPRS95 gives the number of articles the respondent had authored or co-authored that had been published since April 1990.

name: Named as inventor for U.S patent
description: PATENT indicates that the respondent had been named as an inventor for a US patent.

name: Number of articles authored (intervals)
description: ARTC95 gives the number of articles the respondent has authored or co-authored that have been published as of the reference week, grouped in intervals of 5.  The topcode is 51, meaning more than 50 of the respondent's papers were accepted for publication.  A similar variable available for other samples is ARTICLE.

name: Number of articles authored
description: ARTICLE gives the number of articles the respondent has authored or coauthored that have been accepted for publication as of the reference week.  A similar variable is ARTC95.

name: Number of professional society memberships
description: PRMBR reports the number of professional memberships to which the respondent belonged.

name: Attended professional meetings in past year
description: PROMTGI indicates whether or not the respondent attended a professional meeting within the last year.

name: Books or monographs (co)authored accepted for publication indicator
description: BOOKSP reports whether or not the respondent had authored or co-authored at least one published book since October 1998

name: Work similar to what you expected to be doing
description: EXPECTED describes how closely the respondent's work activities fit their expectations from when he/she first completed his/her highest degree.

name: Salary (annualized)
description: SALARY provides the respondent's salary for the principal job.  Respondents are asked to report their basic annual salary, excluding deductions, bonuses, overtime or additional compensation for summertime teaching or research. If the respondent is not salaried, they are asked to provide an estimate of their annual earned income, excluding business expenses.

name: Total earned income before deductions in previous year (public use)
description: EARN provides a public-use and top-coded version of the respondent's earnings before deductions for the year prior to the survey.

name: Total household income: 1996
